data.title: Can Atom have a custom right-click context menu?
data.body:
When right clicking in Atom, I can't help to notice that the popup is my system's sad attempt at a context menu.

I think it would be interesting if we used a custom right-click context menu in the document, or even a frameless `BrowserWindow`.  This way its more accessible as a piece of the software.  For things like themes and packages to customize and use.

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'onDidDestroy' of undefined when using standard-formatter package
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open javascript file
2. Use `ctrl+alt+m` to invoke standard-formatter

**Atom Version**: 1.0.19
**System**: "Fedora release
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'onDidDestroy' of undefined

```
At /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/decoration.js:62

TypeError: Cannot read property 'onDidDestroy' of undefined
  at new Decoration (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/decoration.js:62:49)
  at DisplayBuffer.module.exports.DisplayBuffer.decorateMarker (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/display-buffer.js:1319:20)
  at DisplayBuffer.module.exports.DisplayBuffer.decorateFold (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/display-buffer.js:1720:19)
  at DisplayBuffer.module.exports.DisplayBuffer.handleBufferMarkerCreated (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/display-buffer.js:1709:14)
  at /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/display-buffer.js:5:61
  at Emitter.module.exports.Emitter.emit (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/event-kit/lib/emitter.js:82:11)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.markerCreated (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:1354:20)
  at MarkerStore.module.exports.MarkerStore.createMarker (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/marker-store.js:332:21)
  at MarkerStore.module.exports.MarkerStore.markRange (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/marker-store.js:149:19)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.markRange (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:695:31)
  at DisplayBuffer.module.exports.DisplayBuffer.createFold (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/display-buffer.js:843:95)
  at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.createFold (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2571:33)
  at Selection.module.exports.Selection.fold (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/selection.js:759:19)
  at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.foldSelectedLines (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2523:19)
  at TextEditor.atom.commands.add.stopEventPropagation.editor:fold-selection (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-element.js:574:19)
  at atom-text-editor.newCommandListeners.(anonymous function) (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-element.js:306:32)
  at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:245:29)
  at /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:3:61
  at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:524:16)
  at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:347:22)
  at HTMLDocument.module.exports.WindowEventHandler.onKeydown (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/window-event-handler.js:184:20)

```
### Commands

```
     -4:34.9.0 settings-view:check-for-package-updates (atom-workspace.workspace.scrollbars-visible-always.theme-zenburn.theme-one-dark-ui.find-visible)
     -0:01.4.0 editor:fold-selection (atom-text-editor.editor.emacs-plus.mark-mode.is-focused)
```
### Config

``` json
{
  "core": {
    "themes": [
      "one-dark-ui",
      "zenburn"
    ]
  },
  "editor": {
    "invisibles": {},
    "fontFamily": "Hack"
  }
}
```
### Installed Packages

``` coffee
# User
clipboard-plus, v0.5.1
color-tabs, v0.1.8
color-tabs-regex, v0.2.2
emacs-plus, v0.9.8
minimap, v4.16.0
pigments, v0.18.1
standard-formatter, v1.2.0
zenburn, v3.0.0

# Dev
No dev packages
```

data.title: Optimize markers via new layers API and treap-based index
data.body: This PR improves the responsiveness of find-and-replace and other marker-intensive tasks by adding a layer-oriented API for working with collections of related markers and upgrading to a new implementation of the marker index. Searching for `e` in `jquery.js` now blocks the UI thread for ~1 second instead of ~3.2 seconds. Inserting newlines in this file with the markers present now takes ~10 ms instead of ~35 ms. I still need to make the changes to find-and-replace backwards compatible and merge them after merging these changes. ## API Changes ### Marker Layers A huge problem with our existing implementation is that creating markers emits synchronous events to support existing packages and core APIs. We needed a way to opt out of these event handlers for high-volume use cases, and marker layers were a good way to do this. - `TextBuffer` - `.addMarkerLayer({maintainHistory})` Creates and returns a `MarkerLayer` object. If `maintainHistory` is `true`, markers will be restored on calls to undo/redo. - `.getMarkerLayer` Retrieve a marker layer based on its id. - `MarkerLayer` Some highlights: - `.markRange` Creates a marker. - `.getMarker` Gets a marker by id. - `.findMarkers` Queries the marker layer. - `.onDidUpdate` Called asynchronously whenever markers are created, updated, or destroyed. Can be used without being a drag on performance, but you'll have to re-query any state you're interested in between calls. - `.onDidCreateMarker` This is needed to support our current synchronous selection APIs, but it shouldn't be used on layers that will contain a large number of markers because it slows down insertion. - `.copy` Create and return a new marker layer with all the same markers. - `TextEditor` - `.addMarkerLayer({maintainHistory})` Creates and returns a `TextEditorMarkerLayer`. - `.getMarkerLayer` Retrieve an editor-level marker layer based on its id. - `TextEditorMarkerLayer` This is a wrapper around a buffer-level `MarkerLayer` object and shares the same id. - `.markBufferRange` Create a marker. - `.markScreenRange` Create a marker. - `.findMarkers` Query markers with the same API as `TextEditor.prototype.findMarkers` ### Marker Layer Decorations Another huge source of slowness in find and replace is that we decorated each marker individually. Now that we have marker layers, we can decorate an entire layer in the same way, avoiding a ton of allocations. - `TextEditor` - `.decorateMarkerLayer(layer, properties)` Accepts a `MarkerLayer` or `TextEditorMarkerLayer` and the same properties that `decorateMarker` takes. It creates a decoration for every marker in the layer based on these parameters. This won't work for custom gutter decorations or overlay decorations, but _will_ work for highlights, line, and line number decorations. Returns a `LayerDecoration`. - `LayerDecoration` - `setPropertiesForMarker(marker, properties)` This can be used to override the properties of a particular marker in the layer. We needed this to support the "current result" in find and replace without major changes to the package code. Pass `null` to clear the override. ## New Marker Index ![marker-binary-tree](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1789/10924350/062ead24-823b-11e5-85ee-ffd1e77df82f.png) This PR also incorporates a new binary-tree-based [marker-index](https://github.com/atom/marker-index), which replaces the previous b-tree-based index in text-buffer. It offers better and more predictable performance... about 33% faster on my insertion tests (from 1.6 second to 1 second) and an order of magnitude faster at splicing. 1 second is still too long to block the UI thread, so we may still need to background the index population. I would like to experiment with a C++ implementation and see what it buys us, since it's a straightforward implementation that should be fairly easy to port. ## Performance Improvements Now on to the good part... the improvement. This shows results from 3 implementations. The current version, marker layers with the old index, and marker layers with the new index. ### Without marker layers (current implementation) #### Inserting ~20k markers: ~3.2 seconds #### Inserting newlines ~35 ms per keystroke ### Old marker index #### Inserting ~20k markers: 1.6 seconds #### Inserting newlines ~30 ms per keystroke Zooming in, the newline insertion contains 3 ~5ms calls to `MarkerIndex.prototype.splice`: #### Memory consumed 36.2 MB ### New marker index #### Inserting ~20k markers ~1 second #### Inserting newlines ~7-10 ms per keystroke Only 1 significant splice operation, 0.8ms. #### Memory consumed 34.8 MB (not a huge savings)

data.title: Add PPA instructions for Ubuntu
Atom incorrectly detecting changes to files with changed line endings when git has core.autocrlf set
data.body:
I'm having an issue where git on the command line doesn't report a file as changed, but Atom is showing the file as changed in the tree view.

Opening the file shows +22, -22 in the stats indicator in Atom, but doesn't show any individual line in the file as changed. (There are no bars indicating changed lines on the left.) If I change the file, the changed lines are shown as changed in the bars on the left, but no other lines in the file are shown as changed (as the stats indicator would have you believe).

Showing hidden characters lets me see that the line endings in the file are indeed different, but these changes are ignored by git, as per my settings.

Now here's something weird I discovered in the process of debugging this issue. This might actually be a bug in git...

``` text
$ git config core.autocrlf
input
$ git config --global core.autocrlf
$ git config --local core.autocrlf
$ git config --system core.autocrlf
```

git seems to think my `core.autocrlf` setting is set to "input", but I don't have it set to that anywhere in my settings. Why? I have no idea. Anyone know if this is a bug in git? And if so, where do I report it?

Setting `core.autocrlf` explicitly seems to resolve the inconsistency, causing Atom to once again ignore changes to line endings:

``` text
$ git config --global core.autocrlf input
```

This difference of behavior is confusing though. Is this a bug in Atom? Or perhaps a bug in git, git-utils, or maybe libgit2?

Note I'm running `git version 2.6.2.windows.1` on Windows 10, and Atom v1.1.0.

Note: _Issue migrated from akonwi/git-plus#302._

data.title: The application /Applications/Atom.app cannot be opened because its executable is missing.
data.body:
Hi I'm getting the error when running atom from the command line in OSX 

ProductName:    Mac OS X
ProductVersion: 10.11.1
BuildVersion:   15B42

Atom Version: 1.1.0

data.title: Add portable mode on Linux
data.body: /cc @raelyard

data.title: Dragging over tabs should switch tabs
data.body: It would be great if when you are drag and dropping something onto atom pages if you drag over the editor tabs it would switch tabs to the editor who's tab you are hovering over. Some delay would likely be ideal.

data.title: Remove atom home duplication
data.body:
Set `ATOM_HOME` env var in the render process based on the value from the load settings set via the main process.

This removes duplication of `ATOM_HOME` computation.

/cc @raelyard

data.title: Command Line Parameter to set Atom to Portable Mode
data.body:
I'm porting this from #9229 and retargeting to master.

From @raelyard:

 This is an enhancement to Portable Mode PR #8442 to provide a command line parameter for Atom to automatically set up a Portable Mode directory (a .atom directory as a sibling to the directory containing the Atom executable).

This uses -p and --set-portable
as a straw-man example of what would be the desired parameter.

This copies the .atom home from the default location to the portable location, assuming someone who has been using Atom and wants to go portable would want to take with them what they have already installed/configured.  This may or may not be a good assumption.

data.title: Hitting escape on multiple selection lands cursor at point of origin...
data.body:
See gif:

![Wonkish multiple selection behavior.](http://g.recordit.co/OMKFOkmlQT.gif)

I would expect hitting escape would leave the cursor (and jump the page) to the final selection. In this case (in the gif) that would be the first line, not the second line. For reference, Sublime Text behaves this way—forgetting the point of origin.

Perhaps there are some programmers who prefer this behavior, and its actually a feature? If so, is there a way that I can change the behavior on just my instance? It's (sorry) driving me batty.

data.title: Atom weird bug with space character
data.body:
Hello I open this issue as it happens more and more often on my Atom editor.
Sometimes when I hit space I have the following character
` `
Which looks like a normal space character but isn't, it results in PHP fatals errors and Javascript errors
`Parse error: syntax error, unexpected ' ' (T_STRING), expecting '{'`
For something like
`function my_function() {`
If I replace the space part by a new space it works again.

This is really weird and I don't know what the difference is between ` ` and ` `but it happens occasionally on my files resulting in mind blowing errors. Looks like the first one is` `
If you need something more I will be happy to share it since it's really annoying.

data.title: Settings lost when launching atom by opening an associated file
data.body:
When atom is not running and i am opening an associated file (e.g. test.php), this will launch atom, but all settings are reset to default (theme, core settings and package settings).

When atom is launched as described, the console shows that almost all packages failed to load:

``` javascript
Failed to load package named 'project-manager' c:\Users\myuser\.atom\packages\project-manager\lib\project-manager.js:3
```

And i get the following error:

``` javascript
TypeError: Expecting a function in instanceof check, but got undefined
  at c:\Program Files (x86)\Atom\resources\app\src\view-registry.js:70:34
  at Array.find (native)
```

When atom is already running the file is just opened in the last focused editor window and the settings are untouched.

This happens on `Windows 7` and `Windows 10` running `Atom 1.0.19` and `1.1.0`.

data.title: Multiple crashes on Windows 10
data.body:
Atom crashes on startup on Windows. It happens about once per week, and the only solution is to delete the whole ~/.atom directory.
I can't understand what triggers the problem, sometimes it happens after installing a new package, but removing it and clearing everything inside compile-cache won't solve the problem. Sometimes it just happens out of nowhere, one day it works, and the next it won't open. I'm sorry I can't be more helpful in describing the issue, but I can't narrow it down to a specific event. The last 3 crashes were today (11/03), October 28th and October 15th.
I'm running Atom 1.1.0 on Windows 10. The editor loads and it shows and empty pane, and the menu bar on top only shows the "Atom" tab, but then it stays idle for a few seconds and then Windows notifies that the program froze.

data.title: Package precedence
data.body:
I'm very new to this all, I got here because my latex syntax high lighting makes my [red-wavy-underline](https://atom.io/packages/red-wavy-underline) disappear.
As a web developer I'm aware of the z-index and also that the order you load your css files can make a huge difference.

Is Atom using any kind of [precedence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_operations) for its packages, and if, where can I change it / which categories are there?

For me (non native EN), my spell-check is essential and number one priority for latex (and code), of course followed by the code [standard](http://standardjs.com) of your team.

data.title: How do I configure TAB behavior in Atom?
data.body:
Hi

I've been using Atom for a while, just opened up some code that I created in Atom using `vi` and the spacing etc. is crazy, nothing lines up etc.!

I have always used Notepad++ for years before switching to Atom, and had that set to `Use spaces instead of TABs` and `Tab size is 2 spaces`.

How do I emulate this behaviour in Atom? Never use tabs, and when the tab key is hit just insert 2 spaces.

data.title: Window menu doesn't list open windows
data.body:
In Atom 1.2.0-beta0, OS X 10.11.1.

The “Window” menu is no longer listing the open Atom windows, making it difficult to switch between them. The problem still occurs in safe mode.

data.title: Alt + Mouse Selection to select multiple lines
data.body:
One of the features I miss most in Atom is column selection usually done using the ALT Key + Left mouse on mac:

https://www.sublimetext.com/docs/2/column_selection.html

Would love to see that in Atom.

data.title: Slow start up time launching from Dock or Mission Control
data.body: I noticed that when I launch Atom from my applications that the loading time is significantly longer than if I use the command line. I'm running a 2014 MacBook Pro. I've attached a screen shot of Time Cop showing several packages that have added milliseconds to the load time. Is there any way to speed up Atom without having to disable packages as I use many of the packages on a regular basis?

``` json
    "lineHeight": 1.7
  }
}
```
### Installed Packages

``` coffee
# User
base16-ocean-dark, v0.3.0
git-diff, v0.42.0

# Dev
No dev packages
```

data.title: Can't style indent-guide if using Shadow DOM
